title: AT&T Eyes $16- to $17-a-Month Streaming Service in Strategy Shift
summary: New package is expected to include HBO, Cinemax and Warner Bros. content for barely more than HBO's current streaming service. AT&T Inc.'s WarnerMedia is discussing plans to package HBO, sister channel Cinemax and its vast Warner Bros. TV and movie library into a streaming service costing between $16 and $17 a month, according to people familiar with the matter, a strategy aimed at keeping the media giant competitive against lower-priced offerings in a crowded field.

title: Dollar Falls Ahead of Jobs Report
summary: Investors will closely monitor employment data for signs of how robust the U.S. economy is. The dollar slipped ahead of the release of the monthly jobs report Friday.

title: Overthrow the Prince of Facebook
summary: Big tech has become too powerful and abusive. We know enough about it to break up its dominance.. I'll start with a personal experience and then try to expand into Republicans and big tech.

title: A Democrat Deflates a Trump 'Scandal'
summary: An email from Sen. Amy Klobuchar shows that officials acted on the policy merits.. Democrats have grown expert in these Trump days at creating fake scandals. So it's refreshing to read a previously undisclosed email in which Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, a presidential aspirant, destroys a leading narrative even as she highlights her own party's excesses.

title: Federal Judge Wraps Up Hearings Into CVS-Aetna Deal
summary: Judge Richard Leon is focusing on antitrust settlement between companies and Justice Department. WASHINGTON-Two days of unprecedented court hearings on CVS Health Corp.'s acquisition of Aetna Inc. wrapped up without a firm date for when a federal judge would rule on a Justice Department settlement that allowed the deal, and legal uncertainty for the merged firm could last well into the summer.

title: 'Humour' Review: No Laughing Matter
summary: A distinguished literary critic muses about humor, with observations that are occasionally amusing but more often somewhat tedious.. Ifirst read a book by Terry Eagleton when I was a graduate student in English literature 20 years ago. Mr. Eagleton was the English-speaking world's most famous leftist literary critic, and I was even more of a hidebound conservative reactionary than I am now. But I loved what I read in "Criticism and Ideology: A Study in Marxist Literary Theory" (1976). Maybe some of its arguments were tendentious, but the author had a terrific gift, as I thought, for explaining and assessing the ways in which a diverse array of left-wing intellectuals have interpreted great works of the imagination. Mr. Eagleton expanded his scope in "Literary Theory: An Introduction" (1983), the book for which, notwithstanding its many detractors, he is justly famous. His style in these works is erudite, but only in the way a good professor is erudite-his aim is to teach.

title: On China Trade, Trump Is All Business
summary: His entrepreneurial instincts drive his hardball approach.. President Trump's tough approach to trade with China is evidence that he's an entrepreneur at heart. While his real-estate business is larger than the average independently held company, he has the instincts of a small-business owner, which are different from those of a corporate CEO.

title: The Culture War Behind Israel's Political Crisis
summary: An ultra-Orthodox rabbi explains the Jewish schism over traditionalism.. Every election since Israel's founding has yielded a governing majority-until now. Last week Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that he had failed to form a coalition in the Knesset despite his apparent victory in April's vote.

summary: His new plan will play on the coasts but it gives Trump an opening.. Joe Biden's advisers said a month ago that he planned to pitch his climate agenda to the "middle ground." title: A Bad French Auto Romance

title: Nationalism and D-Day
summary: Trump's words show how sovereignty can serve Western values.. Hell froze over Thursday, as Donald Trump delivered a speech in Europe that even his critics applauded. His remarks on the 75th anniversary of the D-Day landing at Normandy were stirring, and the occasion offers a lesson about the values that unite the Western alliance despite the personal and political feuds of the moment.

summary: Chivalry is vital even at the risk of personal embarrassment.. Young readers may be shocked to learn of a time before cellphones in America. If your car broke down on a lonely stretch of road, getting stranded wasn't merely inconvenient but dangerous.

title: New Yorkers Are Living Longer Than Ever
summary: New research also found large gaps in life expectancy in cities where racial segregation is more common. Older New Yorkers, who make up roughly 13% of the city's population, are living longer than ever, according to a new report released Thursday from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

title: A Dangerous Plan to Limit U.S. Nukes
summary: If Congress bans low-yield weapons, it would hand an advantage to Moscow and make war more likely.. Unbelievably, Congress is considering a restriction on the ability of the U.S. to defend itself. The proposal, tucked into this year's defense bill, would prohibit the Pentagon from spending money to deploy smaller, low-yield nuclear warheads on submarine-launched ballistic missiles. These weapons have been scheduled to be deployed before the effective date of this year's defense bill, meaning that this provision would pre-emptively recall the weapons from deployment.

title: A 'Hamilton' Ticket for $849? Experts Call That a Bargain
summary: Hit Broadway show that has grossed over half a billion dollars may still be underpriced, despite hefty costs for a seat. With a current top ticket price of $849, "Hamilton" is the costliest show to see on Broadway-by a wide margin. But to hear some economic experts tell it, even that high-priced seat may be a steal. In effect, "Hamilton" is underpricing itself, they say.

title: Mirror, Mirror: Who's the Most-Photographed NYSE Trader of All?
summary: Until recently, it was Peter Tuchman. But now, a new, younger contender has emerged.. If you've read more than one or two articles about the stock market, you've probably seen a picture of Peter Tuchman-who for years has been known as the most photographed trader at the New York Stock Exchange. With his wild Einstein-style hair, vivid expressions and theatrical gestures, he has been the go-to guy for photographers and photo editors who need an action shot about the markets.

title: The Real Difference Between Cheap and Pricey Beauty Products
summary: With a new influx of skin care products at extreme price points, the psychology of why we buy what we buy has never been more complex. A peek into the mind-vanity connection. WHEN SHE TRAVELS, Amanda Goddard, a content editor in New York, checks two bags: one for clothes, the other for skin-care products. "And that's just for what I put on my face," the 28-year-old said. Her load includes a Hepta-Peptide Serum, Lactic Acid Serum, Rosehip Oil and Retinol Serum, all from budget brand the Inkey List. "I just shamelessly love skin care," she admitted. The amount Ms. Goddard spent on all four sophisticated elixirs? About $50, a solid deal in a beauty landscape where a serum can easily run into the triple digits.

title: Stocks Extend Gains on Dovish Central-Bank Signals
summary: Dow and S&P 500 add to this week's rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced for a fourth consecutive session Thursday, buoyed by supportive commentary from global central banks that helped shore up investor confidence earlier this week.

summary: There is a cleaner, widely used alternative to heating with gas-heat pumps.. title: Trump's Mexican Tariffs Will Hurt the U.S.
summary: If we were to really increase tariffs on Mexican goods by 25%, it is reasonable to estimate that the Mexican economy would suffer and the flow of illegal immigrants would actually increase.. Regarding "Trump Prepares Mexico Tariffs" (page one, May 31): There is nothing like using an economic weapon to solve a political problem. President Trump ranks with Herbert Hoover in using tariffs, which increase costs for businesses and consumers. The result is that profits decrease and markets drop. The U.S. is correct in addressing issues with Mexico and China, but it is approaching problem-solving in a bilateral manner in a multilateral world. If we were to really increase tariffs on Mexican goods by 25%, it is reasonable to estimate that the Mexican economy would suffer and the flow of illegal immigrants would actually increase.

title: Poetry Can Offer a Last Connection to the Demented
summary: My father's mind was grasping for a common humanity around which we could coalesce, if only for a moment. And we did.. Dr. Michael P.H. Stanley's "Macbeth" citation, "tomorrow creeps in this petty pace," resonated with me ("The Bard on the Ward," op-ed, June 5). During my first visit with my father, recently admitted to a Memory Care facility, I watched him anxiously do a word search. Suddenly, he began to recite poetry I remember him declaiming when I was child. Among the poems was "If" by Rudyard Kipling. Clearly, completely, with an unspoken touch of regret, he recited the full poem. And yet, he couldn't remember how I got my last name. As Rudyard Kipling so aptly puts it: "If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew / To serve your turn long after they are gone, / And so hold on when there is nothing in you / Except the Will which says to them: 'Hold on!'" My father's mind was grasping for a common humanity around which we could coalesce, if only for a moment. And we did.

title: Those Quiet, Bashful Finns Shouldn't Rush to Change
summary: Perhaps we should hire the Finnish to teach Americans how to be quiet.. I was recently stuck in the waiting room of an auto dealership, trying to focus on my Wall Street Journal, but my brain was being assaulted simultaneously by Muzak from the sales floor, inane talk shows from the TV near my seat, Sesame Street jingles from the kids' play area and frequent offers by well-meaning staff members to bring me beverages. Perhaps we should hire the Finnish to teach Americans how to be quiet ("We're Finnish. Small Talk Is Hard. We Are Taking Lessons," page one, May 29).

title: Treasury Yields Move Higher
summary: U.S. government-bond prices generally slipped ahead of a much-anticipated jobs report. U.S. government-bond prices moved lower Thursday, led by declines in shorter-term debt, one day ahead of a much-anticipated jobs report.

title: Household Net Worth Rose 4.5% in First Quarter
summary: Growth in household debt slowed to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.3%. American households more than made back their losses from last year's stock market turbulence in the first quarter of 2019, according to a Federal Reserve report released Thursday.

title: 'Big Little Lies' Review: A Comedy of Excess
summary: The hit series returns with fresh direction; sinister, soapy delights; and a pitch-perfect Meryl Streep.. "I want to watch the Stanley Cup Finals!"-there's an obvious compromise: the return of "Big Little Lies," which will provide enough high-heeled drama and nasty slap shots to satisfy the entire family.

title: Gold Extends Winning Streak as Dollar Falls
summary: Prices are near their highest levels of 2019. Gold prices rose Thursday, extending their longest winning streak in nearly 18 months as the dollar fell.

title: 'Dark Phoenix': Taking Flight, Then Crashing and Burning
summary: Sophie Turner stars in this scrambled X-Men origin story.. Eight years ago, in "X-Men: First Class," the X-Men team of gifted mutants defused the Cuban Missile Crisis, thereby saving the world from nuclear Armageddon. It's no surprise, then, that they manage to save the space shuttle Endeavour from disaster on its maiden flight in "Dark Phoenix," the latest and apparently the final installment of the notoriously erratic franchise. Endeavour's savior is an X-Man who's a woman, Jean Grey/aka Phoenix (Sophie Turner). Blasting herself into the void, she uses all her superpowers to hold the shuttle together. The episode contains one surprise I can't reveal without spoiling a crucial plot point, and brought another that I couldn't ignore, even though it was inflicted on the film by the theater where my screening took place. Otherwise, the most surprising thing about the production, which was written and directed by Simon Kinberg, is how grindingly dumb it becomes after a promising start.

title: 'The Last Black Man in San Francisco' Review: A City in Flux
summary: Joe Talbot's beautiful debut feature is a poetic meditation on life in the City by the Bay in a time of gentrification.. Until you open your heart to "The Last Black Man in San Francisco," it's hard to get your mind around this piercingly beautiful debut feature by Joe Talbot. So many themes flowing through it, so many hypnotic visions of the City by the Bay as it's seldom seen. And such a delicate balance between the dominant tone of gentle longing and an undertone of anger and grief. There's no plot to speak of, but none is needed. The story concerns the stories we need to tell ourselves, and the feelings come through strong and clear. What the hero longs for most strongly is a place he can call home.

title: 3 Key Instagram Feeds to Follow If You Love Architecture and Design
summary: Indulge your design fascination with photos of rooms decorated in the 1980s and '90s, the seemingly endless styles of Japanese public bathrooms, and an obsession with architectural pattern. For anyone who wants to revisit the décor of the 1980s and '90s-nostalgically rather than derisively-there's Sheldon Trewin's @jpegfantasy. The prevailing aesthetic? "Postmodern paradise meets executive penthouse meets your grandmother's living room," said the Vancouver digital-home technician. He scans photos from thrifted books, sourcing and dating images that showcase the return to luxury and flash that accompanied the post-'70s economic boom. Think strong pastels filtered through glass-brick partitions, and platform tubs clad in colored square tiles and mystifyingly bright-white grout.

title: TV Broadcasters Outside Parliament Can't Shake 'Stop Brexit Steve'
summary: Protester, with megaphone, wins cat-and-mouse game with TV reporters covering U.K.'s break with EU by getting into shot every time; BBC built a scaffold, Steve Bray got taller signs. title: Finally, an Airbnb for Campers (and Glampers)
summary: These websites-outdoorsy riffs on accommodation-reservation services-help you find prime spots to pitch a tent. ADDING CONVENIENCE to sleeping in the rough, a few reservation websites and apps let you browse campsites throughout the U.S. as easily as you use Airbnb to find more urban shelter. Hipcamp, the most comprehensive, lists some 360,000 places to camp, glamp or sidle up in an RV, buttressing each entry with intel about the amenities (or lack thereof), nearby activities and photos. While this kind of research once took hours, Hipcamp promptly spits out choices as varied as summer wildflowers-from a campsite on California's Tomales Bay (only accessible by kayak) to a spot on a working ranch in Montana (beware cattle drives). Too fussy for tents? Go quasi-camping in a riverside cabin in upstate New York, furnished with a record player. Earlier this year, Hipcamp began listing details on national and state parks and other public lands, though you'll need to book those separately. Tentrr, a similar but smaller site, focuses mostly on glamping accommodation, while the Dyrt, which posts Yelp -like reviews for campgrounds, recently added a booking function as well.

title: Rules for Robot Cargo Ships Could Be Years Away, Regulator Says
summary: International Maritime Organization chief outlines cautious approach as developers seek advances for autonomous technology on the water. title: Volkswagen's Record-Breaking EVs May Help Us Forget Dieselgate
summary: After the success of its all-electric I.D R racer, Volkswagen plans to spend $50 billion on EVs in hopes of erasing the memory of Dieselgate. Dan Neil follows the redemption tour. ON MONDAY driver Romain Dumas and the VW Motorsport team summoned lightning out of a clear blue sky. Blessed with near-perfect conditions at Germany's Nürburgring test track, Mr. Dumas, at the wheel of Volkswagen 's all-electric ID.R speedster, powered around the 12.94-mile course in a breathtaking, barely visible 6:05.336. That figure is second overall only to another green arrow, Porsche's 919 Hybrid Evo, an unlimited gas-electric hybrid that did the deed last year in 5:19.546.

title: ECB Raises Prospect of Rate Cut, Follows Fed Lead
summary: Federal Reserve officials have indicated they could lower interest rates if the economic outlook worsens. VILNIUS, Lithuania-European Central Bank President Mario Draghi opened the door to interest-rate cuts for the eurozone economy on Thursday, a significant policy shift that amplifies a global trend toward easier monetary policy to combat weaker growth.

title: The Crazy, True Story Behind the Pinky Ring Loved by Nicole Kidman, Michelle Obama and Serena Williams
summary: Shilpa Yarlagadda started her fine jewelry company, Shiffon, in her Harvard dorm room. It's become a celebrity favorite and she's using half of the profits to fund female-led companies around the world-and she hasn't even graduated yet. Shilpa Yarlagadda was in the middle of figuring out how to launch a fine jewelry business during her freshman year at Harvard when she learned that MIT had better 3-D printers. Yarlagadda, now a 21-year-old rising junior, wanted to print ring prototypes but Harvard's printers couldn't process castable resin, her material of choice. So she and her friends started going to frat parties at MIT. "If you were a materials science major [there], you could use their printers for free as much as you wanted, so we would just ask the boys," she says. "We were like, 'So, do you even know how to use a 3-D printer? Is that one even good? Do you think it's capable of printing fine jewelry?'"

title: Westmoreland Coal Cleared to Sell Wyoming Mine To Lenders
summary: Kemmerer mine wasn't included in an earlier sale of Westmoreland assets in chapter 11. Westmoreland Coal Co. is set to unload its Wyoming mine to lenders after an earlier deal to sell the mine fell through.

title: The Ancient Origins of the Vacation
summary: Once a privilege of the elite, summer travel is now a pleasure millions can enjoy.. Finally, Americans are giving themselves a break. For years, according to the U.S. Travel Association, more than half of American workers didn't use all their paid vacation days. But in a survey released in May by Discover, 71% of respondents said they were planning a summer vacation this year, up from 58% last year-meaning a real getaway, not just a day or two to catch up on chores or take the family to an amusement park.

title: Rise in U.S. Worker Productivity Could Be Difficult to Maintain
summary: Year-over-year gain of 2.4% in the first quarter was still the best in nearly a decade. title: A Levee Fails and an Illinois Town Is Thrown Back in Time

title: A Chic Mediterranean Island For the Whole Family
summary: With its fine food and pristine beaches, the Spanish island of Formentera ensures the parents are just as giddy as the kids. MY HUSBAND, Adam, looked longingly at Ibiza's hilltop Old Town as the ferry pulled away from the port and embarked on its brief voyage to Formentera. Decades before he became a father with an office job in London, Adam worked as a club promoter on the party island of Ibiza, off the eastern coast of Spain. The experience was short-lived and, ultimately, ill-fated, but it had a lasting impact, and Adam's tales of strobe-lit revelry with a host of n'er-do-wells are still trotted out on a regular basis.

title: Roger Federer vs. the New and Improved Rafael Nadal
summary: The 11-time French Open winner is breaking serve at higher rates than ever before in his career, somehow taking the best part of his game and making it even better. PARIS-Rafael Nadal has always been tennis's snarling creature of habit. He takes ice cold showers before every match. He constantly adjusts his shorts and rubs his nose. He lines up his on-court drinks just so. His catalog of tics and routines has become so recognizable over the years that the tennis world sits up and notices even the slightest change.

title: The Golden State Warriors Are...Underdogs?
summary: The Toronto Raptors have a 2-1 lead in the NBA Finals. They're playing like they believe they're better than the two-time defending champions. And they might be right.. It was the time of year when he had freedom to experiment, and Nurse was considering the variety of lineups he can play on any given night.

title: Rate Cuts Aren't as Certain as Markets Think

In the case of interest rates, though, investors have changed their minds a lot, but the facts don't look much different.

title: Fiat Chrysler Withdraws Offer to Merge With Renault
